block.p: International A3-15 U.S. BANNING EXPORTS TO CHINA The United States announced it would ban American exports of almost $1 billion in high-technology goods to China over the next two years to punish Beijing for selling sensitive missile technology to Pakistan in violation of international agreements. A1 VIOLENCE PLAGUING GEORGIA Violence continues to torment Georgia, a country in the Caucasus. The sound of gunfire is so frequent in the capital residents now call it Chicago. The Metekhi Palace, Georgia's sole luxury hotel, has a sign that asks guests to check their firearms. A1

International A3-15 U.S. BANNING EXPORTS TO CHINA The United States announced it would ban American exports of almost $1 billion in high-technology goods to China over the next two years to punish Beijing for selling sensitive missile technology to Pakistan in violation of international agreements. A1 VIOLENCE PLAGUING GEORGIA Violence continues to torment Georgia, a country in the Caucasus. The sound of gunfire is so frequent in the capital residents now call it Chicago. The Metekhi Palace, Georgia's sole luxury hotel, has a sign that asks guests to check their firearms. A1

POLAND'S SHIFT TO THE WEST On his first visit to Poland as the leader of Russia, President Boris N. Yeltsin was shown how much this former Warsaw Pact nation wants to join the Atlantic alliance. A3 BERLIN MAY STOP ITS FACELIFT Berlin is to make a series of decisions that could change its face for years to come. These could involve the closing of the famous Schiller Theater and its arts center, and abandoning the reconstruction of the Stadtschloss, which was among Europe's best-known palaces. A10 THREAT TO CZECH GYPSIES Scores of Gypsies in the Czech Republic are being forced by local authorities to leave northern Bohemia, and many of them may lose Czech citizenship when a new law goes into effect in January. A11 DISSIDENCE IN STATE DEPT. A number of State Department staff members have quit in protest over American policy toward the former Yugoslavia. Four mid-level officials have resigned because they say they can no longer support a policy they feel rewards Serbian aggression and backs the dismemberment of a sovereign country. A12 U.N. AID REACHES MOSTAR United Nations trucks piled high with food and medicine entered the embattled city of Mostar, passing enraged Croatian women trying to prevent the badly needed aid from reaching Muslims. A12 BOSNIA APPEALS TO WORLD COURT Less than a week before the Government of Bosnia and Herzegovina must decide whether to accept the country's division into three ethnic republics, lawyers for Bosnia asked the World Court to rule that any such division would be "null and void" and to declare an arms embargo against Bosnia illegal A13 United Nations counts on American rangers in Somalia. A8 National A16-18, B8 OPTIMISM FOR OZONE LAYER The buildup of the industrial chemicals responsible for depleting the earth's protective ozone layer has slowed substantially, Government scientists report. If the trend continues, they say, the buildup should stop before the year 2000. A1 SHIFT OF POWER IN TV CBS has joined the other networks in abandoning demands that cable systems pay large sums for the right to carry network programing, in a striking demonstration of how the balance of power in television has shifted from the broadcasters to the cable industry. A1 BORED AND POOR IN A DESERT A few years ago, two California counties were the most rapidly growing region in the United States. But many of the settlers have now lost their jobs and are stranded with their new homes in the middle of the desert, part of a fading mirage of ever-rising prosperity. A1 UPROOTED BY FLOOD When the Missouri River barreled through a tiny farm town this summer, the unthinkable happened. The river washed away the cemetery, and nearly 900 coffins floated downstream. A1 ARTS LOSE FUNDING IN COBB COUNTY A Georgia county commission that condemned homosexuality voted to cut off all money for the arts in the face of a proposal to limit financing to projects that support "community, family-oriented values." A16 JUSTICE IS ACCUSED The Chief Justice of the Rhode Island Supreme Court, accused of using his position to give legal work to a business partner, stepped down from the bench temporarily. A16 FINE FOR SHIPPING COMPANY A foreign-owned shipping company that admitted funneling laundered money to dozens of California politicians since 1989 was fined $895,000, the largest political ethics violation in the nation's history. A16 ANOTHER HOPE LOST Another critical moment for the Mars Observer mission came and went in silence, dashing one of the last remaining hopes that the mission might be salvaged. A18 Metro Digest B1 INDICTMENT FOR SHEIK The Federal Government charged that Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, an Egyptian cleric known for his fiery sermons, was a leader of a terrorist group that orchestrated acts of violence, including the World Trade Center bombing. A1 Business Digest D1 The Home Section C1-11 At home with Roger Tory Peterson, reluctant earthling. C1 In her own images, a new 'Aunt Bumps.' C1 Furniture's next wave: putting six kits to the test. C6 Arts/Entertainment C13-20 New York Film Festival emphasizes the personal epic. C13 American vanguardists thrive in Europe. C13 In Aspen, a metaphor for change. C13 Sports B10-17 Baseball: Three-division play almost a done deal. B11 Yankees topple White Sox. B11 Braves sweep Giants. B11 Mets fall to the Reds. B13 Obituaries D19 Editorials/Op-Ed A20-21 Editorials The nines arrive -- too fast. The House and the Hatch Act. To be precise. Letters William Safire: Bare-chested leaders. Terence Turner: Brazil's guilt in the Amazon massacre. Mark Mathabane: Appearances are destructive. Elizardo Sanchez: Let Castro lead the way. Chronicle B6 Bridge C16 Crossword C18
